I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Following a request from the Government of Nepal for capacity development technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to build the capacity of government 
institutions for waste management, ADB’s country programming mission in April 2010 made a 
provision for the Capacity Building for Waste Management TA.1 The country operations and 
TPF FPT
business plan (COBP) 2011–2013 reconfirmed the processing of this TA.2
TPF FPT 
 
2.  An ADB fact-finding mission visited Nepal from 8 to 12 July 2010. This report is based 
on the understanding reached with the government during the mission regarding the impact, 
outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  outline 
terms of reference for the TA.3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
TPF FPT
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Urbanization  and  waste  management.  In  2001  Nepal's  urban  population  was  a 
relatively  low  14%  of  the  total  population,  covering  58  municipalities.  However,  internal 
migration into urban areas is increasing rapidly and the urban population is expected to reach 
24% by 2016. While productivity in urban areas is higher and poverty substantially lower, 
infrastructure  development  and  service  delivery  have  fallen  behind  in  urban  areas.  Public 
investments  have  not  kept  pace  with  the  growth  of  the  urban  population,  and  urban 
environmental conditions, already deteriorating, have worsened. Solid waste management is no 
exception, particularly in large urban centers, as the problem of uncollected or improperly 
dumped waste has also worsened. This problem is particularly acute outside of the Kathmandu 
Valley, where only 24.1% of households had access to garbage collection and disposal systems 
as of 2003, compared with 83% in the Kathmandu Valley in the same year. 4
TPF FPT 
 
4.  The role of municipalities is often limited to sweeping the streets and dumping the waste 
on the nearest river bank or tract of open land. Modern waste management techniques such as 
source-separated door-to-door collection, recycling facilities, and sanitary landfills have not yet 
been introduced in most municipalities. Municipalities generally lack the necessary skills or 
resources to manage the waste in a proper manner. Locating a sanitary landfill site is often 
challenging, reflecting a "not-in-my-backyard" attitude in subject communities. In the Kathmandu 
Valley, opposition from communities near landfill sites often blocks the transportation of waste, 
resulting in garbage piling up along the roadside. Besides being a nuisance, this poses serious 
public health risks. Municipalities urgently need to introduce integrated waste management 
systems, in partnership with local communities and the private sector.   
 
5.  The potential to use solid waste as a resource and improve waste management systems 
in municipalities is high. However, efforts by municipalities to promote recycling have largely 
failed. As about two-thirds of the waste generated in Nepal is organic, composting organic 
waste could significantly reduce the cost and environmental impact of waste management and 
remove some of the pressure on landfills. However, to be sustainable, composting operations 
must produce good quality, marketable compost. Nepal lacks quality standards for composting 
and poor management has forced many composting systems to stop operating.

6.  Policy  and  institutional  framework. The Solid Waste Management and Resource 
Mobilization  Center  (SWMRMC)  was  created  under  the  Solid  Waste  Management  and 
Resource Mobilization Act (1987, amended in 1992) as an autonomous body under the Ministry 
of Local Development (MLD). Its functions include (i) undertaking basic construction, repair, and 
maintenance work to control solid waste and obtain the cooperation of municipalities; (ii) making 
arrangements for the disposal of solid waste in a pollution-free manner; (iii) making available 
technical  advice  and  other  assistance  for  any  individual  or  body  connected  with  the 
management and control of solid waste; and (iv) providing or arranging to provide training in 
matters concerning solid waste management and environmental sanitation. However, the act 
came  into  force  only  in  the  Kathmandu,  Lalitpur,  and  Bhaktapur  municipalities  (all  in  the 
Kathmandu Valley), and does not cover other municipalities. In accordance with the functions 
granted, the SWMRMC is managing transportation and disposal of waste at a landfill in the 
Kathmandu Valley. The Local Self Governance Act (1999), which assigns municipalities the role 
of carrying out and managing the collection, transportation, and disposal of solid waste, makes 
the SWMRMC's role unclear even as it continues to manage waste in the Kathmandu Valley. 
The  current  support  provided  to  municipalities  outside  the  Kathmandu  Valley  includes 
undertaking environmental impact assessment studies for new landfill sites, organizing training 
programs for municipal staff, and providing a portion of land acquisition costs for new landfill 
sites. However, assistance is ad-hoc rather than systematic, and has not led to improvements 
on the ground.  
 
7.  Taking into account the circumstances described above—in particular the urgent need to 
reformulate and strengthen institutional arrangements for improving solid waste management in 
the country—the government, led by the MLD, has drafted a new Solid Waste Management Act. 
This new act defines the roles and responsibilities of local bodies, redefines the role of the 
SWMRMC, establishes a Solid Waste Management Council (SWMC), and includes provisions 
for collecting service charges and involving the private sector in solid waste management. The 
SWMRMC will be renamed the Solid Waste Management Technical Support Center (SWMTSC). 
The center will focus on supporting municipalities' solid waste management efforts and will not 
directly  undertake  solid  waste  management  operations.  The  SWMC,  to  be  chaired  by  the 
Minister of Local Development, will be responsible for formulating policy pertaining to solid 
waste management. The Solid Waste Management Act has already been proposed to the 
Parliament, and deliberation at the legislative subcommittee was completed in July 2010. As 
ADB  has  approved  the  Secondary  Towns  Integrated  Urban  Environmental  Improvement 
Project,5 which includes components to improve solid waste management systems in Birgunj 
TPF FPT
and Butwal municipalities, strengthening the policy and institutional framework and technical 
capacity of the support agency (SWMTSC) will complement ADB’s intervention at the project 
level. The TA will also build on the findings from an ongoing regional TA that focuses on 
innovations in scaling up organic waste management.6

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be effective and efficient services provided to municipalities by 
the SWMC and SWMTSC. This will be measured by the number of municipalities that initiate 
improvement  of  solid  waste  management  utilizing  the  newly  established  regulatory  and 
institutional  framework—including  support  from  the  SWMTSC  or  solid  waste  management 
policies  and/or  regulations  issued  by  the  government.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be 
strengthened capacity of the SWMC and SWMTSC under the well-defined policy, regulatory 
and  institutional  framework.  Indicators  will  include  the  number  of  regulations,  guidelines, 
standards,  etc.,  issued  by  the  government,  through  adequate  consultations  with  relevant 
stakeholders  and  the  number  of  municipalities  seeking  and  obtaining  support  from  the 
SWMTSC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Component 1: Supporting the establishment of an effective framework for solid 
waste management. Under the overall direction defined in the Solid Waste Management Act, 
this component will support the establishment of an effective national solid waste management 
policy  and  institutional  framework.  In  accordance  with  the  act,  a  national  solid  waste 
management policy and strategy will be drafted. The act will define new roles and functions for 
the SWMTSC (currently the SWMRMC) and SWMC, based on which regulations and a suitable 
organizational structure for the SWMC and the SWMTSC will be proposed. The regulations and 
policy  will  address  the  formation  of  public–private  partnerships  (PPP)  in  solid  waste 
management.  
 
10.  Component 2: Strengthening the technical capacity of the SWMC and SWMTSC. 
This component will strengthen the capacity of government officials—mainly in the SWMC and 
the SWMTSC—to work within the organizational structure defined in component 1. The capacity 
development  program  will  cover  policy  and  strategy  implementation;  planning,  designing, 
implementing, and operating an integrated solid waste management system, including sanitary 
landfill; promotion of 3R (reduce, reuse, and recycle); technical issues such as landfill design, 
leachate  treatment,  and  organic  composting;  developing  proposals  eligible  for  the  clean 
development mechanism; and designing PPP contracts. A few pilot cases of collaboration 
between the SWMC and/or SWMTSC and municipalities will be supported in order to equip staff 
with  hands-on  skills  and  knowledge.7  Such  support  may  include  development  of  project 
TPF FPT
proposals,  drafting  of  institutional  arrangements,  or  facilitating  the  implementation  of 
arrangements agreed upon among relevant parties.  
 
11.  Component  3:  Supporting  the  development  of  relevant  regulations,  standards 
and/or guidelines for improving solid waste management at the regional and local levels. 
Existing rules and regulations do not enable municipalities to implement effective solid waste 
management programs (although the situation should improve with the expected passage of the 
Solid Waste Management Act in September 2010). This component will support the government 
to first identify missing or ineffective regulations and guidelines, and then to fix them or draft 
new ones. The work will involve close cooperation among all government agencies that play a

Potential areas of support will include: national tariff guidelines (including methodology for tariff 
setting, collection, and administration); specific legal arrangements for PPP; health care waste 
management  regulations;  design  standards  for  sanitary  landfill;  and  standards  for  organic 
compost quality.  
 
12.   Assumptions  and  risks.  As  mentioned,  it  is  expected  that  the  draft  Solid  Waste 
Management Act, which is being deliberated in the Parliament, will be approved in September 
2010. However, the Parliament could end up amending the act and/or delaying its approval. 
While the MLD has assured that the act will be approved promptly and without any major 
changes, consultants will be mobilized only after the act has been approved. If the need arises, 
the scope of the consulting services will be adjusted. Improving solid waste management hinges 
on effective coordination among various ministries and departments, as it involves not only 
municipal (domestic) solid waste but also health care waste and industrial waste, which are 
under the jurisdiction of other ministries. Coordination with other ministries will be enhanced 
through the steering committee (para. 14).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  It is estimated that the TA will cost $600,000 equivalent. The government has requested 
that ADB finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will finance the balance of the 
cost, equivalent to $100,000, through the provision of office space, remuneration for counterpart 
staff (including their field per-diem and transportation), and other in-kind contributions (Appendix 
2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The MLD will be the executing agency and will appoint a TA director at the level of joint 
secretary or undersecretary who will take the lead in supervising all tasks performed by the 
consultants and coordinating the activities of relevant organizations. At the central level, a 
steering  committee  will  be  established  to  monitor  implementation  of  the  TA.  The  steering 
committee, which will be chaired by the secretary (municipal management) of the MLD, will be 
composed of high-level representatives from the National Planning Commission, the Ministry of 
Finance, the Ministry of Physical Planning and Works, the Ministry of Environment, the Ministry 
of  Health  and  Population,  and  the  Ministry  of  Industry,  plus  the  general  manager  of  the 
SWMTSC. The TA director will work as member and the convener of the steering committee. 
The steering committee will meet at least quarterly to discuss overall progress of the TA, 
strengthen interministerial coordination, and provide policy guidance for TA implementation.  
 
15.   The government will provide (i) any relevant documents, data, statistics, information, or 
maps that the government has at its disposal; (ii) qualified counterpart staff (at least one staff 
each from the SWMTSC to respective fields of consultants’ expertise), and their field per diem 
and field transportation; (iii) a TA director from the MLD, to be assigned before the mobilization 
of consultants; (iv) office accommodation and office equipment, including desks, chairs, local 
communication, and utility costs (electricity and water); and (v) logistical assistance for the 
workshops  and  seminars,  including  venue  provision  and  identifying  and  sending  invites  to 
participants.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months, from January 2011 to April 2012. The 
outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. International expertise (9 person-

5
months) will be obtained in the areas of solid waste management policy and PPP. National 
consultants (31 person-months) will have expertise in the fields of solid waste management 
engineering, institutional development, financial management, social development, and legal 
matters.  Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
   
17.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A team of consultants will be recruited under 
one package using the quality- and cost-based method of selection with a standard quality–cost 
ratio of 80:20. A simplified technical proposal will be used for the selection of the consultant firm.  
In addition, a few individual consultants may be engaged through the individual consultant 
selection method to address specific needs of the TA. Some equipment, such as computers and 
printers, will be procured using the shopping method, in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  All  equipment—including  software—
purchased under the TA will be handed over to the MLD or SWMTSC after the completion of the 
TA. ADB will undertake a TA review, in collaboration with the MLD, at least twice a year during 
implementation of the TA. 
 
18.  The consultants will assist the government in organizing workshops at the beginning and 
toward the completion of the TA. In the initial workshop, the framework, approach, objectives, 
and targets of the TA will be shared with participants from government agencies, development 
partners,  the  private  sector,  and  nongovernment  organizations.  Seminars  and  consultation 
workshops will be held as needed during implementation of the TA to solicit the views of 
stakeholders in drafting policies, strategies, regulations, guidelines, and standards. The final 
workshop will review good practices and lessons learned during the implementation of the TA. 
The consultants will ensure coordination with related loans and TAs of ADB8 and programs of 
TPF FPT
other  development  partners—including  those  by  the  United  Nations  Human  Settlements 
Program (UN-HABITAT) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Public–
Private Partnerships for the Urban Environment—to maximize complementarities and avoid 
duplication. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Capacity Building for Waste Management, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objective  
1.  The objective of the assignment is to assist the government in establishing an effective 
framework  for  solid  waste  management  and  to  develop  the  capacity  of  the  Solid  Waste 
Management Council (SWMC) and the Solid Waste Management Technical Support Center 
(SWMTSC) to discharge their mandates as prescribed in the new Solid Waste Management Act. 
Specific outputs will include: (i) support for establishing a policy, regulatory, and institutional 
framework  for  solid  waste  management—including  the  establishment  of  the  SWMC  and 
SWMTSC—and drafting a national solid waste management policy and strategy; (ii) support for 
developing the capacity of the SWMC and SWMTSC; and (iii) support for developing regulations, 
guidelines, and/or standards to improve solid waste management at the regional and local 
levels.  
 
B.  Scope  
2.  The technical assistance (TA) will require about 40 person-months of consulting services 
(9 international and 31 national). The support provided to the SWMC and SWMTSC will enable 
them to deploy their responsibilities as prescribed in the new Solid Waste Management Act. 
 
1.  Specific Tasks of Consultants 
3.  Component 1: Supporting the establishment of an effective policy, regulatory, and 
institutional  framework  for  solid  waste  management.  This  component  will  support 
formulation of a national solid waste management policy framework, restructuring of the Solid 
Waste Management and Resource Mobilization Center (SWMRMC) to take on its new role as 
the SWMTSC, and establishment of the SWMC. Tasks will include, but not be limited to, the 
following: (i) drafting a national solid waste management policy and strategy in accordance with 
the Solid Waste Management Act; (ii) forming links between national agencies and local bodies 
to enforce the act, policy, and strategy; (iii) recommending an organizational structure for the 
SWMC  and  SWMTSC,  with  clear  roles  and  responsibilities  defined;  (iv)  supporting  the 
establishment of the SWMC and SWMTSC, including preparation of a business plan for the 
SWMTSC; and (v) recommending a regulatory framework to promote private sector participation 
in solid waste management. 
 
4.  Component 2: Strengthening the technical capacity of the SWMC and SWMTSC. 
This component will strengthen the capacity of staff, mainly in the SWMC and SWMTSC, in line 
with their responsibilities defined in the component 1. Tasks under this component will include: (i) 
assessing  the  existing  technical  capacity  of  the  SWMRMC  (SWMTSC)  and  other  relevant 
central agencies involved in solid waste management; (ii) preparing a capacity development 
program;  (iii)  implementing  the  capacity  development  program  through  classroom  training, 
workshops,  seminars,  an  awareness  campaign,  and  on-the-job  training;  (iv)  supporting 
dissemination of the Solid Waste Management Act and the national solid waste policy and 
strategy to government agencies, local bodies, and the public; and (v) providing support to a few 
pilot  cases  of  innovative  solid  waste  management  practices.  Elements  of  the  capacity 
development  program  will  include  policy  and  strategy  implementation;  planning,  designing, 
implementing, and operating an integrated solid waste management system involving a sanitary 
landfill; promotion of 3R (reduce, reuse, and recycle); specific technical issues such as landfill 
design, leachate treatment, and organic composting; developing proposals eligible for the clean

development  mechanism;  and  designing  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  contracts.  Select 
municipal representatives will also participate in the capacity development program. A few pilot 
cases of collaboration between municipalities and the SWMC and/or SWMTSC, to be selected 
in consultation with the government and ADB, will be supported in order to equip staff with 
hands-on skills and knowledge. Such support may include developing specific project proposals, 
making  institutional  and  financial  arrangements,  and  facilitating  the  implementation  of 
arrangements  agreed  upon  among  relevant  parties.  In  the  implementation  of  capacity 
development programs, resource persons may be invited, as needed, from the training budget. 
 
5.  Component 3: Supporting the development of effective regulations, standards, 
and/or guidelines for improving solid waste management at the regional and local levels. 
The scope will comprise conducting a thorough assessment of the existing legal and institutional 
framework  of  the  solid  waste  management  subsector,  identifying  missing  or  ineffective 
regulations and guidelines, prioritizing urgent areas of work, and drafting new and/or amending 
existing ones for review and approval by the relevant authorities. The work will involve close 
cooperation among all government agencies that play a role in solid waste management to 
ensure necessary buy-in and effective implementation.  Potential areas of support will include: 
national tariff guidelines (including methodology for tariff setting, implementation, collection, and 
administration);  specific  legal  arrangements  for  PPP;  health  care  waste  management 
regulations; design standards for sanitary landfill; standards for organic compost quality; and a 
set  of  performance  indicators  and  targets  to  serve  as  a  checklist  to  assess  local  bodies' 
performance  on  solid  waste  management.  Consultations  will  take  place  when  the  draft 
documents have been prepared.  
 
C.  Terms of Reference for Team Members 
1.  Team  Leader  and  Solid  Waste  Management  Policy  and  Public–Private 
Partnership Expert (international, 7 person-months)  
6.  The  expert  should  have  experience  in  solid  waste  management  and  PPP  policies. 
He/she should also be fully conversant with the private sector's role in solid waste management 
and be able to conceptualize a framework to augment that role in the context of Nepal. In 
collaboration with the national experts, the expert will: 
(i)  assist the government in drafting a national solid waste management policy and 
strategy; 
(ii)  review  the  existing  structure  of  the  SWMTSC  and  propose  organizational 
structures  for  the  SWMC  and  SWMTSC,  including  staffing  and  resource 
requirements, so that these bodies can perform their mandates as prescribed in 
the Solid Waste Management Act;  
(iii)  support establishment of the SWMC and SWMTSC, including the preparation of 
necessary regulation and a business plan for the SWMTSC; 
(iv)  develop and implement a solid waste management technical training module and 
public awareness program as a part of the capacity development program; 
(v)  undertake a thorough analysis of existing regulations, guidelines, and institutional 
framework pertaining to solid waste management, identify missing issues and 
weaknesses in the existing framework, and prioritize urgent areas of work;  
(vi)  assist  the  SWMC,  SWMTSC  and/or  other  responsible  agencies  in  drafting 
specific regulations, guidelines and/or standards identified and prioritized in the 
analysis;  
(vii)  assess  the  current  regulatory  and  institutional  arrangements  for  PPP,  and 
address the findings in the new solid waste management  policy to promote PPP;

Appendix 3  11   
(viii)  assess the needs for specific legal arrangements for PPP, including solid waste 
management  projects, and if found necessary, assist the government in drafting 
such; 
(ix)  identify and propose suitable pilot cases to be supported under the TA, involving 
innovative approaches such as PPP and a regional approach for solid waste 
management, and provide support to the selected ones; 
(x)  assess  and  identify  suitable  private  sector  participation  modalities  such  as 
design–build–operate,  performance-based  management  contracts,  build–
operate–transfer, and other suitable modalities in solid waste management; 
(xi)  assist  the  government  in  designing  PPP  packages,  including  draft  contract 
documents,  and  develop  key  performance  indicators  if  performance-based 
management contracts are applied; 
(xii)  assist the SWMTSC and/or municipalities in monitoring the implementation of 
agreed-upon arrangements, such as PPP contracts; 
(xiii)  guide, supervise, and support the activities of other experts to undertake the 
defined activities and ensure quality of work; and 
(xiv)  take the lead in ensuring delivery of various outputs of the TA, including all 
required reports. 
2.  Deputy Team Leader and Solid Waste Management Engineer (national, 14 
person-months) 
 
7.  The expert should have an engineering background as well as experience working in 
solid waste management policy development and implementation, including PPP issues. He/she 
will support the team leader to manage the overall TA implementation and assist the team 
leader in undertaking all tasks. Particularly, he/she will:  
(i)  assist the government in drafting a national solid waste management  policy and 
strategy; 
(ii)  undertake a thorough analysis of existing regulations, guidelines and institutional 
framework pertaining to solid waste management, identify missing issues and 
weaknesses in the existing framework, and prioritize areas of work that are the 
most urgent;  
(iii)  take the lead in drafting urgent technical guidelines and standards;  
(iv)  provide inputs in preparing and take the lead in implementing a solid waste 
management  technical training module and public awareness program as a part 
of the capacity development program; 
(v)  develop a set of performance indicators and targets to serve as a checklist to 
assess local bodies' performance on solid waste management; 
(vi)  provide support to selected pilot cases, which may include developing specific 
project proposals and making institutional and financial arrangements;  
(vii)  assess the needs for specific legal arrangements for PPP including solid waste 
management  projects; and if found necessary, assist the government in drafting 
such;  
(viii)  assist  the  government  in  designing  PPP  packages,  including  draft  contract 
documents,  and  develop  key  performance  indicators  if  performance-based 
management contracts are applied; 
(ix)  assist the SWMTSC and/or municipalities in monitoring the implementation of 
agreed-upon arrangements, such as PPP contracts;  
(x)  ensure close coordination with the Ministry of Local Development (MLD), SWMC 
and SWMTSC; and

12  Appendix 3 
 
(xi)  supervise and support other experts' activities under the guidance of the Team 
Leader. 
 
3.  Institutional Development Expert (national, 7 person-months) 
8.  Under the supervision of the team leader and deputy team leader, he/she will:  
(i)  review all policy recommendations of the TA from institutional perspectives; 
(ii)  conduct an institutional capacity analysis (including functions, responsibilities, 
organizational structure, staffing, and budget) of the SWMTSC, SWMC and other 
relevant national agencies involved in solid waste management;  
(iii)  devise links between relevant national agencies and local bodies to enforce the 
Solid Waste Management Act and the national solid waste policy and strategy;  
(iv)  assess readiness for and resistance to change by concerned institutions;  
(v)  identify  capacity  factors  with  measurable  indicators  that  can  map  progress 
toward improved capacity for solid waste management; 
(vi)  based on  the findings, prepare and implement a capacity development program 
that includes strategies for addressing capacity development gaps based upon 
identified priorities consistent with the Solid Waste Management Act;  
(vii)  review  the  existing  organizational  structure  of  the  SWMTSC,  propose  new 
structures for the SWMC and SWMTSC, and support the establishment of these 
structures;  
(viii)  assist  the  SWMTSC  in  preparing  and  finalizing  job  descriptions  and  staff 
qualification criteria for SWMTSC officials; and 
(ix)  identify  and  select  training  agencies,  such  as  the  Nepal  Administrative  Staff 
College,  the  Institute  of  Engineering,  and  the  Urban  Development  Training 
Center,  to  implement  the  capacity  development  program,  with  a  view  to 
establishing functional linkages between the SWMTSC and these institutions for 
the sustainability of training programs. 
 
4.  Financial Management Expert (national, 3 person-months) 
9.  He/she will:  
(i)  review existing practices of collecting solid waste tariffs and other charges; 
(ii)  help the government draft national solid waste management  tariff guidelines;  
(iii)  help the government design and monitor PPP packages, including draft contract 
documents, and help ensure the financial viability of these packages; and  
(iv)  assess the financial implications of the Solid Waste Management Act, the new 
national solid waste management policy, and other regulations and guidelines 
proposed under the TA, and ensure financial feasibility and cost effectiveness. 
 
5.  Legal Expert (national, 3 person-months) 
10.  He/she will:  
(i)  confirm the legal and regulatory coherence of proposed policies and regulations;  
(ii)  review  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory  national  solid  waste  management 
framework and propose a new framework;  
(iii)  draft  acts  and/or  regulations  on  the  basis  of  initial  outlines  or  policy-based 
requirements  identified  by  other  technical  experts,  including  specific  legal 
arrangements for PPP if found necessary; and

Appendix 3  13   
(iv)  lend legal expertise to the designing and monitoring of PPP packages—including 
the drafting of contract documents—to ensure sufficient risk management and 
allocation among contracting parties. 
 
6.  Social Development Specialist (national, 2 person-months) 
11.   The  consultant  will lead  the  work  in  providing  inputs  related  to  participation,  social 
mobilization, and social inclusiveness. He/she will: 
(i)  review and assess the impacts of policy recommendations of the TA on the poor 
and disadvantaged; 
(ii)  advise the government and other team members on raising public awareness 
and  implementing  an  effective  consultation  mechanism  to  ensure  social 
acceptance and buy-in from stakeholders;  
(iii)  prepare procedures and obtain consensus on making social mobilization and 
inclusiveness  an  integral  component  of  solid  waste  management  in  Nepal; 
standard  procedures  should  include  awareness  raising,  information 
dissemination,  social  feasibility  studies,  social  audits,  and  stakeholder 
participation in planning, design, implementation, monitoring, and operation and 
maintenance of solid waste management projects; and 
(iv)  provide  guidance  and  lead  the  work  on  community  mobilization,  behavioral 
change, raising public awareness, and effective consultation in the pilot cases.  
 
12.  The above expertise and inputs are indicative, and may be adjusted in consultation with 
the  government  and  ADB  after  submission  of  the  interim  report.  There  is  provision  for 
unallocated international (2 person-months) and national (2 person-months) consulting inputs 
that will be utilized on an as-needed basis during implementation of the TA. These additional 
experts may be engaged through individual consultant selection.  
 
D.  Reporting 
 
13.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1.5 months of the mobilization of 
the team leader, finalizing the approach and presenting key performance indicators and targets, 
a detailed work plan, and an implementation schedule for the TA; (ii) an interim report within 4.5 
months of the mobilization of the team leader, summarizing the progress made, work achieved, 
prioritized work to be undertaken, and proposed adjustments in expertise and inputs during the 
remaining period; (iii) progress reports 8 months and 11 months after mobilization of the team 
leader that will summarize progress, problems, and challenges facing the TA, suggest ways to 
address any problems, and note major achievements and planned programs for the next quarter; 
(iv) a draft final report 13.5 months after mobilization of the team leader that will summarize 
activities undertaken and results achieved, compare achievements with original targets, review 
problems encountered during implementation and propose actions to remedy those problems, 
and recommend future short- to medium-term programs; and (v) a final report 3 weeks after the 
final workshops and receipt of comments on the draft final report from the government and ADB. 
In  preparing  these  reports,  the  consultants  will  work  closely  with  the  MLD,  SWMC,  and 
SWMTSC.
